subject: Re: Thinking of improving the auto generation of test cases
msgSnippet: ... Hi Saldin, You should really be using the Eclipse plug-in to take full advantage of JUnitFactory, but you can still get a flavor of what it can do
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, saldin samuel <saldin_s@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Kevin,
>
> I have just gone through the demo and it is impressive
> with the parameters of primitive data types such as
> int, String, etc. How about generating the unit tests
> for Objects such as class instances ?
>
> For instance, if my method is:
>
> public Student getFirstStudent(School school)
> {
> }
>
> How do we generate the test data for the classes
> Student and School ? Is there any such kind of demos
> that I can refer to ?
>
> Thanks and Regards,
> Saldin

Hi Saldin,

You should really be using the Eclipse plug-in to take full advantage
of JUnitFactory, but you can still get a flavor of what it can do
non-primitives by cutting and pasting the following code into the web
demo window. It's one java file with a School and a Student class.
The School class has a method addStudent() that takes a Student object.

Note that we also generate a bunch of tests for Student. Why so many
tests for Student? Well, in order to construct the Student object
JUnitFactory has to create both a valid and invalid social security
numbers (SSN) and age parameters. For example, since the age
parameter has a set of conditions (e.g. age > 12) the test generator
will create values for 12 as well as invalid values such as 11.

Have fun with it:

----- CUT AND PASTE INTO JUNITFACTORY DEMO WINDOW ----------------

package school;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class School {

List students;
public School() {
students = new ArrayList();
}

public void addStudent(Student newStudent) {
if (students.contains(newStudent))
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Student already enrolled");
students.add(newStudent);
}

public int getEnrollment() {
return students.size();
}
}

class Student {

String name;
String SSN;

public Student(String name, String SSN, int age) {
validateSSN(SSN);
validateAge(age);
this.name = name;
this.SSN = SSN;
}

private void validateSSN(String SSN) {
if (!SSN.matches("[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{4}"))
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid SSN");
}

private void validateAge(int age) {
if (age < 12 || age > 20)
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Wrong age);
}

}

----------------------- END OF CUT AND PASTE -----------------
